Context:
Program Name: Business Administration – International Business
Code: B131
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,776.00
International Tuition: $17,925.00
Program Location: St. James Campus
Expertise Areas: finance, sales, marketing, human resources
Graduate Roles: forecasting and replenishment analyst, merchandise assistant, purchasing coordinator, logistics coordinator
Skills Acquired: navigating documents and procedures involved in global supply chain, ensuring organization compliance with international business regulations.

Context:
The text discusses various aspects of international business studies offered at George Brown College's Centre for Business. This centre is part of the School of Management and has accredited partnerships with both FITT (Forum for International Trade Training) and ACBSP (Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs). The FITTskills program, provided in collaboration with FITT, leads to the Certified International Trade Professional (CITP) designation.

George Brown College has earned recognition from ACBSP for fourteen programs, including those in Accounting and Finance, Human Resources, Management, Marketing, and Financial Services. Students can apply for Business Administration – International Business with work experience through program B161. The college also provides field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients.

No specific factual information like years, numbers, or names is mentioned in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – International Business Program B131 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The B131 program at the college requires students to complete 36 courses to graduate. Of these 36 courses, there are 31 mandatory courses, 2 Business electives, and 3 General Education electives. Students may be required to take certain prerequisite courses such as COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) and MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation), which do not count toward the 36 courses required for graduation and will be charged extra for.

Students must complete three General Education courses from at least two of the following categories: Social Sciences, Arts and Humanities, or Science and Technology. Students are also required to make up any failed or dropped courses before they can graduate. These classes can be taken during the day or in the evening through Continuing Education, but students should check with the business office staff to ensure that the Continuing Education courses are equivalent to what is taught in the full-time program.

The following is a list of courses offered in Semester 1 and their respective prerequisites:
- BUS 1038 (Business Concepts) - None
- COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts) - None
- COMP 1010 (Business Computer Applications I) - None
- HRM 1008 (Fundamentals of HR Management) - None
- MARK 1020 (Principles of Marketing) - None
- MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I) - None

The following is a list of courses offered in Semester 2 and their respective prerequisites:
- ACCT 1036 (Principles of Accounting) - None
- BUS 1040 (Business Operations) - None

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered by the college in different semesters. Here's a summary of the factual information:

 Semester 1:
 - Courses: ISITE ACCT 1036 (Principles of Accounting), BUS 1040 (Project Management), COMM 1034 (Professional Communications I), COMP 1115 (Business Computer Applications II), COMP 1010, MATH 1095, MATH 1008, PSY 1129
 - Pre-requisites: NONE

 Semester 3:
 - Courses: ECON 1032 (Macroeconomics), MARK 1002 (Professional Selling), MGMT 1035 (Global Trade Assessment), MATH 1008, STAT 1012, CMMK 1087
 - Pre-requisites: NONE

 Semester 4:
 - Courses: ACCT 2031 (Managerial Accounting), BUS 1038 (Business Law), MGMT 2049 (Supply Chain Management II), STS 1037 (Career Planning & Development)
 - Pre-requisites: ACCT 1036, BUS 1041, MGMT 1035

 Semester 5:
 - Courses: MGMT 1020 (Management Decision-Making), MGMT 2041 (International Sales and Marketing), MGMT 2042 (International Market Entry Strategies), MGMT 2043 (International Supply Chain Management), MGMT 2049, MGMT 3008
 - Pre-requisites: MGMT 4009 & ACCT 2031

 Semester 6:
 - Courses: BUS 3017 (Freight Forwarding), MGMT 2041, MGMT 2029 (International Trade Management), MGMT 2043, MGMT 3006, COMM 1034 & MGMT 1020
 - Pre-requisites: NONE for some courses, MGMT 2043 and MGMT 2041 for others

 The text also mentions that students should select one General Education Elective in Semesters 4, 5, and 6. However, no specific information is provided about what these electives are.

Context:
The following is a list of business electives offered by the college, their prerequisites, and some details about their learning outcomes:

1. Business Research & Report Writing (CMMK 1114) - Prerequisite: None
2. The Business Media in Canada (COMM 1034) - Prerequisite: COMM 1034
3. Principles of E-Business (COMP 1113) - Prerequisite: NONE
4. Negotiation Skills (MARK 2053) - Prerequisite: NONE
5. Field Education (BUS 1067) - Prerequisite: Application only, contact the Centre for Business Office
6. Retail Management (MGMT 2037) - Prerequisite: NONE
7. Customer Service (MARK 2049) - Prerequisite: NONE
8. Field Based Advanced Coaching (RM 2027) - Prerequisite: Application only, by interview only
9. Quality Improvement through Lean/six Sigma (MGMT 3015) - Prerequisite: NONE
10. Coaching for Effective Performance Management (HRM 2030) - Prerequisite: HRM 1008
11. Environmental Economics (ECON 1021) - Prerequisite: NONE
12. Principles of Corporate Sustainability, Social Responsibility and Ethics (applied to some organizations' integrative trade initiatives)

The graduate demonstrates the ability to:
- Conduct an environmental scan to evaluate the impact of world issues on an organization’s international business opportunities.
- Conduct, evaluate and present market research to support an organization’s international business decision-making.
- Prepare and analyze documentation and follow procedures to support the movement of products and services in an organization’s global supply chain.
- Analyze the impact of statutory and regulatory compliance on an organization’s integrative trade initiatives.
- Develop and implement strategies to negotiate effectively within various cultural environments and to address the impact of cultural differences on an organization’s integrative trade initiatives.
- Develop and present an international marketing plan, and evaluate sales strategies that support an organization’s integrative trade initiatives.
- Identify and interpret relevant international financial documents and assess financial strategies that support an organization’s integrative trade initiatives.
- Analyze the impact of an organization's integrative trade initiatives on its human resources management strategies, policies and practices.
- Develop and present an international business plan.
- Plan, implement and evaluate team projects by applying project management principles.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – International Business Program B131 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Program Information:
- The program focuses on corporate sustainability, social responsibility, ethics, and applying current technologies to support integrative trade initiatives.
- Tuition for domestic students is $3,776.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
- Tuition for international students is $17,925.00 for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023.
- Financial assistance is available for this program through OSAP, provided applicants meet eligibility criteria.
- Students are required to have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, including grade 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 Math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
- Mature students without an OSSD can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or consider upgrading to meet the credit requirements.

Note: All fees are subject to change without notice and do not include books, which are to be purchased separately. Students should verify George Brown College fee requirements.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Business Administration – International Business Program B131 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
"Applicants may be required to have grades higher than the minimum requirements stated. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions. International Students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Information sessions are held regularly, sign up for an upcoming session. Contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section for domestic student inquiries. International students can contact a recruitment representative by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page. For financial aid inquiries, please contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section. To make an appointment with an Entry Advisor, please review these frequently asked questions. For inquiries related to the Centre for Business and its programs, contact business@georgebrown.ca or call (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160."

Extraction:
- Applicants may need grades above minimum requirements
- College/University credits may qualify for exemptions
- International students must visit the International Admissions page
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges

- Information sessions available, sign up for an upcoming session
- Contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section (domestic inquiries)
- International students can contact a recruitment representative by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page
- Financial aid inquiries: FinAid@georgebrown.ca or Financial Aid section
- Make an appointment with an Entry Advisor by reviewing FAQs
